newsitem.title: USA: U.S. OPTIONS FOCUS/Technology stocks may drop more.
newsitem.headline: U.S. OPTIONS FOCUS/Technology stocks may drop more.

text.p: As U.S. technology stocks attempted to halt their recent correction, investors continued to trade both put and call options, particularly on industry bellwethers and volume leaders, traders said Tuesday.
Jesse Stamer, a designated primary market maker at the Chicago Board Options Exchange, said technology stocks appear to have further downside to go before recovering.
"I would expect a little more downside," he said. "It appears every morning they try to firm up and by mid-morning they're in full retreat."
In late trading, the technology heavy Nasdaq composite index .IXIC was down 13.82 points at about 1,322. It had reached a session high of 1,345 in early trade.
"It's a trend market," Stamer said. "The sellers step away in the morning and they start to come in in mid-morning and the trend continues."
Traders said options investors appeared to be both buying and selling throughout the sessions.
Put and call options on technology stocks were the most active issues on all five options exchanges.
Intel Corp options led the pack, with the February 155 call trading 6,400 contracts.
Intel shares were down 3-3/4 at 147-7/8, off their 146-1/2 session low, on more than 16.6 million shares. The stock had risen to 154-3/4 in early trading before sliding.
International Business Machines Corp shares edged 1/8 higher to 142-7/8 after dropping about six points Monday.
At the CBOE, the IBM February 150 call was most active, with volume of about 3,750 contracts.
The February 145 call traded about 2,600. The February 140 and 145 puts also were busy.
Options on shares of 3Com Corp remained heavily traded at the Pacific Stock Exchange, where a few Microsoft Corp options also were busy.
Stamer said he has seen more trading from firms rather than from retail customers and that the firms appear to be expecting more volatility in the group.

"What's interesting is that the earnings cycle is over and they (the firms) are looking to buy February, March, April, July, all the way out," he said. "So it appears the firms are expecting more volatility in the future rather than less."
One leading technology company that still has quarterly earnings due is Hewlett-Packard Co, which recovered 1-1/8 to 50-1/4 after dropping 2-3/4 Monday.
John Streibich, in the Hewlett trading crowd at the CBOE, said volatilities in the near term options on Hewlett had climbed to the mid-50 area from around 35.
"They're anticipating a big move," he said. "The question is which way. The stock could go to 60 or it could drop back down to the 40s. It's anybody's guess."
He noted that other technology stocks, like IBM and Cisco Systems Inc, had big moves after reporting earnings. ((--G.Crawford, 312 408 8750/Email: derivatives@reuters.com))
